# Biglaw Firm Matches Bonuses... After A Little Drama
## Another 11th hour switch.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 29, 2022 at 11:43 AMDecember 29, 2022 at 12:32 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/foley-hoag-bonuses-2022/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20Bonuses…%20After%20A%20Little%20Drama)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/foley-hoag-bonuses-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/foley-hoag-bonuses-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[UPDATE: Moments after posting this story, we received an update. Follow the whole story but know that the moral of the story is that the firm reversed course after associates voiced concerns.]

It seems as though firms are committed to using the final week of 2022 to announce disappointing bonus news. After [Shearman’s bonus match](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/shearman-bonus-2022/) came attached with a new and previously unannounced hours requirement, another firm has put out a “match” that only applies to associates who exceed the long-standing hours benchmark.

The good news is that Foley Hoag is matching the market scale… for some people. As a reminder, here’s the market bonus scale that we’re talking about.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
2022 $15,000 (prorated based on start date)
2021 $20,000
2020 $30,000
2019 $57,500
2018 $75,000
2017 $90,000
2016 $105,000
2015+ $115,000

Counsel will be getting $125K.

BUT… this only applies to associates and Counsel in good standing who exceed 2000 billable hours this year. That’s a brand new requirement and a requirement that the firm is imposing retroactively. Per a tipster:

Most notable is Foley Hoag has had an 1850 billable target for years and that’s what is told to law students during recruiting. Even throughout this year, the firm acknowledged it was a generally slow year and that the billable target continues to be 1850.

However, as noted in the email memo, the new billable target is 2000 hours, which was announced on Dec 27 and applies retroactively.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
For those who met the target that Foley Hoag asked associates to meet until this week, but didn’t meet the unannounced 2000 target, the firm is only issuing 70 percent bonuses. The memo does not do the math — probably because it doesn’t want to put these numbers in writing to be easily pasted into a future document that might alert prospective associates that the compensation figure comes with a heavy caveat — but we’ll do the math for them.

2022 $10,500 (prorated)
2021 $14,000
2020 $21,000
2019 $40,250
2018 $52,500
2017 $63,000
2016 $73,500
2015+ $80,500

Counsel would get $87,500 in this scenario.

While this is better than stripping associates of bonuses altogether based on a last second ploy to foist the partnership’s pain of a bad year on the employees least responsible for the shortfall, it’s still a rotten way to end the year for associates who made their own business decisions this year based on the expectation that billing 1850 would put them in the firm’s good graces. More importantly, it pulls the rug out from under associates who stayed with the firm during a slow year thinking that they’d be getting that much needed student loan repayment balloon check.

So partial congrats, I guess?

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
The memo is reproduced on the next page.

UPDATE: But THEN, two days after issuing this bonus memo, the firm changed course. In a memo sent out today, the firm notes:

After issuing our memo describing the 2022 bonus policy earlier this week, a number of associates spoke to firm management about a memo issued in connection with the 2021 bonus policy that they believed applied to future years, including 2022. We are persuaded that this is a viable reading of the 2021 memo, and we think it is important to satisfy the good faith expectations of our exceptional associates and counsel, without whom the firm could not have achieved the successes of the past year. Therefore, for 2022, we will be following the 2021 policy by paying the “Cravath” scale to associates and counsel in good standing starting at 1850 billable hours, and by paying 70% of Cravath scale to associates and counsel in good standing with between 1700 and 1849.9 billable hours (and will pay Cravath scale to the class of 2021 regardless of billable hours). Bonuses below 1700 billable hours remain discretionary. Revised memos and additional payments will be issued shortly to impacted associates and counsel. We will revisit this issue for 2023, as it has always been the firm’s intention to address bonuses on a year-to-year basis. We apologize for the confusion, and once again thank everyone for their hard work this year.

Congratulations everyone and good for the firm for making it right!

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. # When Biglaw Firms 'Needed Bodies,' They Just Offered Partnership Titles To Associates
## What an interesting way to get laterals in the door.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 12, 2022 at 3:41 PMApril 13, 2022 at 8:47 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/when-biglaw-firms-needed-bodies-they-just-offered-partnership-titles-to-associates/&text=When%20Biglaw%20Firms%20‘Needed%20Bodies,’%20They%20Just%20Offered%20Partnership%20Titles%20To%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/when-biglaw-firms-needed-bodies-they-just-offered-partnership-titles-to-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/when-biglaw-firms-needed-bodies-they-just-offered-partnership-titles-to-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Firms used this as a way to lure those senior associates away from one firm to another. They needed bodies. The only way they could get people to jump ship was to offer partnership on day one.

— Adam Oliver, CEO and co-founder of Firm Prospects, commenting during an interview with [Law360](https://www.law360.com/legalindustry/articles/1479262/more-associates-are-exiting-to-take-partner-job-offers) on Biglaw firms that have offered counsel or partner titles to associates as leverage during the lateral hiring process.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Morning Docket: 07.16.18
## * A White House spokeswoman claims that Judge Brett Kavanaugh "had never heard any allegations of sexual misconduct or sexual harassment" made against Judge Alex Kozinski prior to last year when everyone else found out, and an extern who worked in Kozinski's chambers while Kavanaugh clerked is backing him up. [[Washington Times](https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/jul/13/kavanaugh-unaware-claims-sexual-harassment-mentor/)] * The art of the deal don't: United Kingdom Prime Minister Theresa May says that President Trump told her she should sue the European Union instead of negotiating when it comes to Brexit options. There's no real cause of action, so she says that won't be happening -- not like that's something that has ever stopped Trump before. [[Vox](https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/7/15/17573274/theresa-may-trump-brexit-sue-eu)] * President Trump leaned heavily on Biglaw partners for his latest nominations to the federal judicary. Perkins Coie, K&L Gates, and Barnes & Thornburg could soon see representation on the Ninth Circuit, the Western District of Washington, the Western District of Pennsylvania, and the Northern District of Indiana. [[The Recorder](https://www.law.com/2018/07/13/trumps-latest-judge-nominees-heavy-on-big-law-include-perkins-coie-partner-for-ninth-circuit/)] * After months of debate, a panel has finally recommended that Florida State rename the law school building via legislative action. It currently recognizes former Florida Supreme Court Chief Justice B.K. Roberts., a " staunch segregationist" who once tried to deny a black student's admission to U. Florida's law school. [[Tallahassee Democrat](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2018/07/13/fsu-panel-recommends-removal-eppes-statute-roberts-name/782284002/)] * "For better or worse, I have become an agent for hope for those that are opposing this president." Michael Avenatti is famous for being President Trump's biggest critic, but he's "using that platform for good." In addition to Stormy Daniels, he now represents parents whose children were separated from them at the border. [[AP](https://apnews.com/3376ba934d1c44fc9bf820597de4da33)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 16, 2018 at 8:39 AMJuly 15, 2018 at 3:21 PM
0

# Former Linklaters Partner Gets Jail Time For Sexually Assaulting Student Intern
## The offending partner was punched in the face by another partner after the assault took place.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 16, 2018 at 9:45 AMFebruary 16, 2018 at 9:01 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/former-linklaters-partner-gets-jail-time-for-sexually-assaulting-student-intern/&text=Former%20Linklaters%20Partner%20Gets%20Jail%20Time%20For%20Sexually%20Assaulting%20Student%20Intern)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/former-linklaters-partner-gets-jail-time-for-sexually-assaulting-student-intern/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/former-linklaters-partner-gets-jail-time-for-sexually-assaulting-student-intern/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A former Linklaters partner in Germany has been sentenced to more than three years in prison for the sexual assault of a student that occurred in 2014 at a firm party. According to [LawFuel](http://www.lawfuel.com/blog/sexual_assault-2/), that student was reportedly an intern at the firm.

Thomas Elser, a former tax partner at Linklaters, reportedly came to blows with Laurenz Schmitt, another former partner at the firm, in the aftermath of an office Oktoberfest party. [Legal Cheek](http://www.legalcheek.com/2014/12/two-linklaters-partners-fall-on-swords-after-oktoberfest-punch-up/), which reported on this story when it occurred, noted that Schmitt was attempting to protect the female intern from Elser’s advances. Schmitt punched Elser in the face (a crime for which Schmitt later received a seven-month suspended sentence), and both partners left the firm after the incident following an internal investigation. [Legal Cheek](http://www.legalcheek.com/2014/12/two-linklaters-partners-fall-on-swords-after-oktoberfest-punch-up/) has more on what happened:

[S]ources close to the firm suggest that the two lawyers — both partners in the Munich office — had a disagreement over how much one of them should impinge on the personal body space of a young female student attending the party.

It is understood that Schmitt took the view that Elsner had stepped over that invisible line, so he landed several punches in a bid to get the tax specialist to back off.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Linklaters partners, both current and former, served as witnesses during Elser’s trial. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/international/2018/02/15/former-linklaters-partner-sentenced-to-three-years-in-prison-for-sexual-assault/) has some additional details on the investigation and trial:

“We have always been mindful that there is a young student at the center of this case,” a Linklaters spokesperson said. “That concern has guided our behavior and priorities throughout.”

Linklaters conducted its own internal investigation of the incident, which was led by London-based litigation partner Christa Band and former senior partner Robert Elliott.

A number of current and former Linklaters partners were called as witnesses during the trial including Band, Frankfurt banking partner Carl-Peter Feick, Frankfurt tax partner Jens Blumenberg, Munich tax partner Rainer Stadler and former German private equity head Rainer Traugott, who left the firm for Latham & Watkins in early 2016.

Elser was sentenced to three years and three months in prison.

[Former Linklaters Partner Given Three-Year Prison Sentence for Sexual Assault](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/international/2018/02/15/former-linklaters-partner-sentenced-to-three-years-in-prison-for-sexual-assault/) [American Lawyer]
[Two Linklaters partners fall on swords after Oktoberfest punch-up](http://www.legalcheek.com/2014/12/two-linklaters-partners-fall-on-swords-after-oktoberfest-punch-up/) [Legal Cheek]
[Linklaters Partner Gets Three Years’ Jail After Oktoberfest Sexual Assault](http://www.lawfuel.com/blog/sexual_assault-2/) [LawFuel]

# Bonus Matching In New York And Silicon Valley!
## Perhaps people aren't excited enough about these bonuses.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 6, 2018 at 11:46 AMDecember 6, 2018 at 11:14 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/bonus-matching-in-new-york-and-silicon-valley/&text=Bonus%20Matching%20In%20New%20York%20And%20Silicon%20Valley!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/bonus-matching-in-new-york-and-silicon-valley/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/bonus-matching-in-new-york-and-silicon-valley/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Last week, Kramer Levin joined the ranks of the Cravath matching firms with a full match for all of its U.S.-based associates in its New York and Silicon Valley offices. We’re sorry we didn’t get this news out to the masses sooner, but we only learned ourselves with a tipster noticing that we had never received word before now.

Is it that these amounts seem so ho-hum that no one is truly jazzed to get them? After the adrenaline rush of the summer salary bump, maybe these amounts feel too de rigueur to associates. Be careful about taking these numbers for granted. Over the life of Above the Law, bonuses have been both much higher and much lower, so don’t fool yourselves into thinking this is a schedule everyone should just expect.

Maybe some good old-fashioned Biglaw passive aggression is what we need around here to remind everyone to let us know the moment their firms announce bonuses. So here we go: It’s okay tipsters, we’re not mad… we’re just disappointed.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
In any event, Kramer Levin joins the ranks of firms handing out:

2018 $15K prorated
2017 $15K
2016 $25K
2015 $50K
2014 $65K
2013 $80K
2012 $90K
2011 and earlier $100K

While Kramer Levin did get its announcement out in a timely manner, paying out in a timely manner is a different story altogether. The firm’s memo notes that bonuses are “expected” — whatever that means — to be paid on February 15, 2019. That’s a mighty fine set of golden handcuffs you folks got there!

Check out the memo on the next page.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Will Biglaw Ever Return To Normal? Ehh, Nope, Probably Not.
## Remote work policies are likely here to stay -- for good.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 10, 2022 at 4:46 PMJanuary 10, 2022 at 2:40 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/will-biglaw-ever-return-to-normal-ehh-nope-probably-not/&text=Will%20Biglaw%20Ever%20Return%20To%20Normal?%20Ehh,%20Nope,%20Probably%20Not.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/will-biglaw-ever-return-to-normal-ehh-nope-probably-not/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/will-biglaw-ever-return-to-normal-ehh-nope-probably-not/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Every time a firm has put a date down for return to office normalcy they’ve had to revisit it, and I think that’s more than likely to continue to happen.

— Legal consultant Kent Zimmermann, commenting on the fact that Biglaw firms planning for a return to a pre-pandemic relative normalcy of in-office work [may not ever see that day come](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/01/07/with-two-years-of-experience-big-law-takes-a-different-approach-to-covid-surge/). Flexible face-time policies have worked for many elite firms for some time, and throughout the coronavirus crisis, remote work has brought “financial fortunes” to Biglaw and has not affected attorney performance.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 06.07.18
## * Stormy Daniels has accused her former lawyer of being a Trump puppet, which I think is called a Trumpet. [[Politico](https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/06/stormy-daniels-trump-puppet-630313)] * EPA Senior Counsel Sarah Greenwalt has resigned because lawyers always find a way to bolt a sinking ship. [[The Cut](https://www.thecut.com/2018/06/scott-pruitt-epa-millan-hupp-sarah-greenwalt-resign.html)] * Judge orders Above the Law all-star Richard Luthmann to get a psych evaluation. [[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2018/06/06/judge-orders-trial-by-combat-lawyer-get-psych-evaluation/)] * Law schools are failing students of color, which is less of a newsflash than something people need to be constantly reminded about. [[Nation](https://www.thenation.com/article/law-schools-failing-students-color/)] * Philly hears from dozens of criminal justice experts speak out over a proposed sentencing algorithm that they say will further cement racial inequalities. Because it will. [[Philadelphia Inquirer](http://www.philly.com/philly/news/crime/philadelphia-pennsylvania-algorithm-sentencing-public-hearing-20180606.html)] * Global law firms are returning to Tokyo so aging partners can live out Lost in Translation. [[International](https://www.law.com/2018/06/05/international-law-firms-are-opening-offices-in-tokyo-again/)] * In-house attorneys produce another music video to convince people to call velcro "hook-and-loop." # Jobs Of The Week: In-House And Boutique Opportunities
## A totally remote in-house job -- the hire can be based anywhere in the United States.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onDecember 18, 2020 at 12:51 PMDecember 18, 2020 at 12:02 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/jobs-of-the-week-in-house-and-boutique-opportunities/&text=Jobs%20Of%20The%20Week:%20In-House%20And%20Boutique%20Opportunities)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/jobs-of-the-week-in-house-and-boutique-opportunities/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/jobs-of-the-week-in-house-and-boutique-opportunities/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

As this tumultuous year draws to a close, [bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/bonuses/) get paid out, and COVID-19 vaccines give hope that the end of the pandemic might soon be in sight, now is a good time to explore new career opportunities. Here are two for your consideration.

First up: an entirely remote in-house opportunity, which we are handling exclusively at Lateral Link. An exciting and dynamic technology company that went public earlier this year is looking for a securities lawyer with at least five years of law firm or in-house experience to handle preparation of the company’s SEC filings. Because the company is in the process of going completely remote, you can sit anywhere in the United States, giving this job incredible flexibility. You must be admitted to a state bar, but which state bar doesn’t matter.

The hours are expected to be extremely reasonable. The company offers excellent benefits — health insurance (75 percent of costs covered), dental insurance, a 401(k) with a generous match, 24/7 mental health counseling, career coaching, and more — and boasts a wonderful, friendly culture. If you’re a securities or capital markets lawyer who has been looking for an in-house opportunity, look no further.

Second, for litigation associates with three to four years of Biglaw experience, a plaintiff-side securities litigation boutique in New York is looking to hire. The work is interesting, dynamic, and fast-paced; you won’t be stuck on these giant Biglaw cases that drag on for five or 10 years. Expect to have stand-up opportunities, such as arguing motions, very soon after arriving. If you’re tired of going to court but never getting to speak, then you might appreciate this post.

This boutique is open to considering associates from a fairly wide range of backgrounds. We’re also working with a number of other litigation boutiques that seek associates with strong academic records from top schools, federal clerkship experience, and a year or two of experience at a top Biglaw firm. Compared to their Biglaw counterparts, boutiques offer smaller (and often more collegial) environments, more responsibility at an earlier stage of your career, and enhanced partnership prospects.

If you might be interested in any of these opportunities, please reach out to me by email: [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com). Thanks, and happy holidays!

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s](http://laterallink.com/) team of expert contributors. This post is by [David Lat](https://www.laterallink.com/team/david-lat/), a managing director in the New York office, where he focuses on placing top associates, partners and partner groups into preeminent law firms around the country.

Prior to joining Lateral Link, David founded and served as managing editor of Above the Law. Prior to launching Above the Law, he worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz in New York, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. David is a graduate of Harvard College and Yale Law School. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices worldwide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](https://www.laterallink.com/clients-testimonials/) to find out more about us.

# A Big Week For Not Knowing The Law
## From Elon Musk's deposition to law school protests, a lot of folks forgot to look up the actual law this week.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 17, 2024 at 1:20 PMApril 17, 2024 at 12:18 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/a-big-week-for-not-knowing-the-law/&text=A%20Big%20Week%20For%20Not%20Knowing%20The%20Law)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/a-big-week-for-not-knowing-the-law/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/a-big-week-for-not-knowing-the-law/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We continue breaking down [the U.S. News & World Report law school rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-2024-2025-u-s-news-law-school-rankings-are-here/) and the chaos that its new methodology introduced. And we know exactly [who to blame for breaking these rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/us-news-law-school-rankings-disregard-holdouts/). Elon Musk recently went in for a deposition defended by Quinn Emanuel’s Alex Spiro and [earned a motion for sanctions](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/quinn-emanuel-proposes-using-time-travel-to-avoid-sanctions-motion/). And a [Berkeley Law protest goes viral](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/berkeley-student-dinner-protest/), but all the “free speech” talk misses the mark.

# Another Biglaw Firm Shaves Associate Salaries In What Is An Increasingly Common Move
## More Biglaw salaries take a hit.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 28, 2020 at 12:46 PMApril 28, 2020 at 12:58 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/another-biglaw-firm-shaves-associates-salaries-in-what-is-an-increasingly-common-move/&text=Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Shaves%20Associate%20Salaries%20In%20What%20Is%20An%20Increasingly%20Common%20Move)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/another-biglaw-firm-shaves-associates-salaries-in-what-is-an-increasingly-common-move/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/another-biglaw-firm-shaves-associates-salaries-in-what-is-an-increasingly-common-move/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Manatt, a Biglaw firm with $313,200,000 in 2018 gross revenue making it 107th in the Am Law 200, finds itself in a similar position as many of its peers. The economic uncertainty surrounding the novel coronavirus sweeping the globe is weighing on firms, and they’re looking for ways to cut costs and preserve cash flow until this whole mess (hopefully) blows over. In Biglaw, one of the go-to methods to trim costs has been to slash salaries, and it looks like Manatt is on board with this approach.

According to tipsters at the firm, Manatt has cut the paychecks of all attorneys by 20 percent — annualized to a 13 percent pay cut. Certainly not as[ severe a pay cut](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/50-percent-pay-cut-schiff-hardin/) as some firms have undertaken, but also [a far cry](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/the-biglaw-firms-rolling-out-good-news-for-now/?rf=1) from those that have managed to get by without any austerity measures. Hopefully, this will be the only cut the firm needs to make to get through the COVID-19 craziness.

We reached out to the firm for comment, but have not yet heard back.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# How Contract Analytics Can Unlock Business Value
## This free white paper explores the unique problems that only contract analytics solutions can solve.
By Above The Law and DocuSign  
onJune 9, 2021 at 12:12 PMJune 9, 2021 at 12:36 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-contract-analytics-can-unlock-business-value/&text=How%20Contract%20Analytics%20Can%20Unlock%20Business%20Value)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-contract-analytics-can-unlock-business-value/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-contract-analytics-can-unlock-business-value/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
While numerous businesses have invested in contract lifecycle management technology, these systems rarely deliver insights about contracts’ actual contents — let alone analyze what contractual language means in ways that enable smarter, faster decisions. 

To do that, businesses need a CLM system supported by world class analytics.

And while CLM and contract analytics are inherently intertwined — or, in some cases, converging, as companies like DocuSign quickly advance toward full integration — understanding the differences between these solution types is a critical distinction for any business leader. 

In this white paper from our friends at DocuSign, you’ll learn:

- The difference between CLM systems and contract analytics;
- The unique problems that only contract analytics solutions can solve; and
- The key benefits investing in this technology can bring to businesses.
Download it today to help your law department increase the business value it provides.

By filling out the form you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its Partners.


####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [DocuSign](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/docusign/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/technology/)

# Resources, Not Brains, Give Biglaw Firms An Edge
## If attorneys at smaller firms were paid the same as Biglaw lawyers, and had the same resources, they would be able to provide similar services.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onOctober 31, 2018 at 10:04 AMOctober 30, 2018 at 9:38 PM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/resources-not-brains-give-biglaw-firms-an-edge/&text=Resources,%20Not%20Brains,%20Give%20Biglaw%20Firms%20An%20Edge)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/resources-not-brains-give-biglaw-firms-an-edge/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/resources-not-brains-give-biglaw-firms-an-edge/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Many might believe that Biglaw firms are better at serving clients because they have brighter and more talented attorneys.  Indeed, numerous top graduates from good law schools end up at Biglaw shops, [since these firms pay more money than attorneys might receive in other roles](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/law-school-tips/).  And there is some truth to the fact that brighter individuals might make better attorneys, especially with cases that involve complicated legal issues.

However, [as someone who has worked at both big and smaller law firms](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/about-jordan/), I have seen firsthand how resources really distinguish Biglaw shops more than intelligence or talent ever could.  As I have said in a few prior articles, [it is my experience that the success or failure of a case is usually preordained by the facts and law of a given matter](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/biglaw-attorneys-tend-to-make-some-pretty-weird-arguments/).  Nevertheless, the resources available at top firms give Biglaw attorneys a better chance at obtaining favorable outcomes for their clients.

One of the biggest resources of a large law firm is a highly-compensated and dedicated workforce.  Since Biglaw attorneys make insane sums of money, they can be expected to work on nights and weekends and log long hours in order to serve their clients.  This is especially important when tight deadlines need to be met or matters must be handled on an exigent basis.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Attorneys who work at smaller firms [are not paid as much](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/extra-money-main-job/), and usually do not work the type of hours that lawyers at Biglaw firms do.  Indeed, attorneys at smaller law firms usually enjoy a more predictable work week [that does not include too much work after hours](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/balance-side-hustles-main-job/).  As a result, they might not have the time to take advantage of certain strategies that require tight deadlines to execute.

In addition, the larger fees charged by Biglaw firms, and the larger budgets for cases, ensure that attorneys at large law firms usually only work on a handful of matters at a time.  Indeed, when I was working in Biglaw, I usually only worked on three or four large cases at once.  However, when I was working at smaller law firms, I was responsible for handling three dozen or more lawsuits at the same time.  When attorneys handle numerous matters, they are usually not able to devote as much attention to each case, and this is another reason why the resources of a Biglaw firm give attorneys at these shops an edge.

Furthermore, Biglaw firms typically have the time and money to think about and plan cases in a way that is not possible at smaller shops.  When I was working in Biglaw, we often had strategy sessions in which we were able to pool our ideas and prepare for each stage of a matter in detail.  This had a positive impact on our cases, since we had more minds thinking about legal issues, and we were able to plan detailed strategies for the matters we handled.

When I was working at smaller law firms, I usually had to handle each case by myself.  Sometimes I received advice from a partner or other attorneys when we socialized around the office, but there were no other lawyers assigned to my cases who could share my workload.  As a result, I was not able to plan each of my cases to the extent possible at larger law firms, and this had an impact on the matters I handled.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
In addition, I did not receive the same type of administrative support at smaller law firms that I had at a Biglaw shop.  When I was working at a large law firm, I had a secretary who could handle administrative tasks, and paralegals who could conduct great legal research.  In fact, the Biglaw shop at which I worked had a library and other resources that were unavailable at other firms.  Furthermore, my Biglaw shop had attorneys in numerous offices who handled a ton of different types of matters, and I could reach out to lawyers in different practice areas if I ever had a question.

When I was working at a smaller shop, my firm only had a few offices, and the one time I asked questions of an attorney in another office, I got a pretty cold response.  In addition, the only resource we had at the smaller firm was access to a legal research platform, and our subscription was limited.  This lack of resources had an impact on my cases and I likely would have been able to do better work if I had the resources of a Biglaw shop.

All told, I am pretty confident that if attorneys at my smaller firm were paid the same as Biglaw lawyers, and had the same resources, they would be able to provide similar services to attorneys in Biglaw.  Of course, there are times when brains and ingenuity can greatly impact a case, and as such, the credentialed attorneys of Biglaw might make the difference in certain scenarios.

However, I have also seen instances in which attorneys at large firms tripped up because they did not know rules about practice that any attorney at a smaller shop would understand because of their experience.  Indeed, the facts and law of a matter limit the extent to which smarts and ingenuity can impact a lawyer’s representation of a client.  In any case, it seems to me that resources, and not brains, give Biglaw firms an edge when representing clients.

# Paul Weiss Goes Dark On Compensation
## Transparency only stands in your way when going after top laterals.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 18, 2024 at 2:47 PMJanuary 19, 2024 at 11:17 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/paul-weiss-goes-dark-on-compensation/&text=Paul%20Weiss%20Goes%20Dark%20On%20Compensation)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/paul-weiss-goes-dark-on-compensation/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/paul-weiss-goes-dark-on-compensation/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In order to boost efforts to recruit the top lateral partners, Paul Weiss has moved even further away from  modified lockstep partner compensation. They’re [reportedly](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/01/11/paul-weiss-hides-partner-pay-inside-black-box-as-firm-shells-out-for-top-laterals/)  adopting a “black box” system that will obscure partner compensation in order to minimize discontent and tensions within the partnership.

As reported by Law.com:

The adoption of a nontransparent pay system comes as leaders at Paul Weiss seek to reduce tensions among partners as the firm widens the spread of compensation with large investments in recruiting and retaining rainmakers from competitors, the people said. In 2023, Paul Weiss recruited a trio of Kirkland & Ellis transactions partners believed to have scored $20 million in annual pay.

Chair Brad Karp hasn’t responded to these reports, but has [previously said](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/09/29/elite-firms-revisit-comp-formulas-as-star-talent-has-extraordinary-leverage/) the firm will do what it needs to do on partner pay in order to say on top of the heap, “We are not doctrinaire and we have adjusted our system in recent years to deal with changing market realities and to maintain our competitive edge.”

Part of the new plan will be a bigger bonus pool for partners — all the better to nimbly respond to changes in a practice area profitability without changing the partners’ shares within the compensation system. As consultant Kent Zimmermann previously noted, “If you’re producing a certain value for firms consistently and then you have a spike, the bonus allows for additional compensation for that spike.”

Other top firms that have moved to a black box on partner comp include Ropes & Gray, Fried Frank, and Jones Day.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon @Kathryn1@mastodon.social.

# Managing Stress As A Lawyer
## The 2022 ALM survey reveals alarming statistics on the mental health of lawyers, with 75% admitting that the profession negatively affects their mental health and almost a quarter having contemplated suicide.
By [ANNA SZYMCZAK - LATERAL LINK](https://laterallink.com/team/anna-szymczak/)  
onMarch 3, 2023 at 11:48 AMMarch 3, 2023 at 12:06 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/managing-stress-as-a-lawyer/&text=Managing%20Stress%20As%20A%20Lawyer)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/managing-stress-as-a-lawyer/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/managing-stress-as-a-lawyer/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s no secret that lawyers are stressed out, anxious, and struggling with mental health. In the 2022 [ALM survey](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/05/10/pandemic-anxiety-wanes-but-legal-industrys-mental-health-struggles-persist/) on Mental Health and Substance Abuse, 35% of respondents said they felt depressed, two-thirds reported having anxiety, 64% said their relationships have suffered due to their work, and a whopping 75% admitted that the profession has had a negative impact on their mental health. Nearly a quarter of respondents had contemplated suicide.

In the face of such grim data, it’s easy to feel discouraged. Many of the factors contributing to these challenges can’t be fixed simply through individual behavioral change. But even so, we shouldn’t do nothing. Managing stress as a lawyer is hard, but your personal choices and actions can make a big difference. As the saying goes: the best defense is a good offense.


Taking a realistic approach

You already know the basic steps to help reduce stress: exercise, limit screen time, set boundaries, get good sleep. Sadly, following those methods isn’t always realistic in the workplace, especially for lawyers. Acknowledging the inherent constraints of the profession, here are some realistic suggestions on how to disconnect and manage stress.

Move your body — even a little bit

Maybe you can’t make it to the gym for an hour every day. But did you know that physical movement releases “[hope molecules](https://medium.com/curious/your-body-can-produce-hope-molecules-9b015ce088e1)” directly into the bloodstream, in as little as 13 minutes? According to Kelly McGonigal, PhD, “every time we move our muscles, we give ourselves an intravenous dose of hope.” Other [studies](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/the-athletes-way/201602/neuroscience-pinpoints-unique-way-exercise-fights-depression#:~:text=The%20UC%20Davis%20researchers%20found,in%20the%20Journal%20of%20Neuroscience.) have shown that physical movement can replenish the neurotransmitters in the brain that, when depleted, are associated with major depressive disorders.

Just [10-13 minutes](https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/exercise-endorphin-high-time-how-long-motivation-study-10-minutes-wiggle-a8325661.html) of vigorous exercise can release “happy chemicals” in the brain. Not a fan of intense exercise? Can’t make it to a yoga class? Try [“joyful movement,” ](https://www.bpl.org/blogs/post/beyond-body-positivity-what-is-joyful-movement/#:~:text=Joyful%20movement%20means%20moving%20your,for%20you%20in%20that%20moment.)which is exactly what it sounds like: moving your body just for fun. On a long conference call but not doing much talking? Put the phone on speaker, stand up, and lightly move. You can walk in place, swing your arms around, stretch your neck, etc. Leave a resistance band in your office and use it to stretch between calls. Short walks around the office are a great idea, and don’t even get me started on the mental health benefits of [sunlight](https://www.tricitymed.org/2018/08/5-ways-the-sun-impacts-your-mental-and-physical-health/) (go outside!). 

Regulating the nervous system

The idea that humans can [rewire their ](https://psychcentral.com/anxiety/how-to-train-your-brain-to-alleviate-anxiety#neuroplasticity-and-anxiety)nervous systems isn’t new, but it’s increasingly talked about in wellness circles. Long story short: the brain’s function is to keep us safe, not to keep us [happy](https://medium.com/personal-growth/your-brain-doesnt-want-you-to-be-happy-it-wants-you-to-be-safe-44d3498229ba#:~:text=But%20the%20most%20overlooked%20fact,brains%20are%2040%2C000%20years%20old.). When the body perceives a threat, stress hormones such as cortisol and adrenaline are released to prepare to “fight or flight.”

The fight or flight response was essential in helping our ancestors evade predators, but it’s [harming](https://www.health.harvard.edu/staying-healthy/understanding-the-stress-response) us in modern life, where the stressors are more like heavy traffic, an important deadline, or too many emails. Research [now shows](https://www.nichd.nih.gov/newsroom/releases/stress) that such long-term activation of the stress system can have a hazardous, even lethal, effect on the body, increasing the risk of obesity, heart disease, and depression. 

While we can’t entirely shut off the body’s stress response (nor would we want to), we can train the brain and body to perceive and respond to “threats” with greater accuracy. A growing number of studies show that [meditation](https://www.apa.org/topics/mindfulness/meditation#:~:text=In%20a%20review%20of%20meditation,reactions%20in%20times%20of%20stress.) and [diaphragmatic breathing](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5455070/) (aka “breathwork”) are incredibly effective for helping regulate the nervous system, thereby eliminating feelings of stress. Next time your thoughts begin to race, your temperature rises, and you sense your heart rate increasing, try practicing [box breathing](https://www.webmd.com/balance/what-is-box-breathing). Slow and steady deep breathing communicates to the body and brain that you are safe, helping to eliminate the stress response.

Be intentional with your free time, and use money to buy more of it

It’s a given that lawyers work long hours and have limited free time, so be sure to use the little time you do have to create habits and routines that can boost your mood and actually help you disconnect from stress. Instead of [doom scrolling](https://www.webmd.com/balance/what-is-doomscrolling#:~:text=Doomscrolling%20can%20send%20your%20mind,you%20usually%20enjoy%2C%20research%20suggests.) on Instagram every morning, take that time for yourself to practice gratitude, stretch, or meditate. 

Another thing you can do is use your golden handcuffs — I mean, salary — to expand your free time. Delegate tasks like cleaning and meal prepping by hiring a professional service. Spend the additional free time (and some more of that money) on effective wellness modalities that aren’t typically covered by insurance, like acupuncture. Alternatively, use your purchasing power to test out some gadgets that may boost mental health: shakti mats, LED therapy lights, infrared sauna blankets, or wearable devices like heart rate trackers. If money keeps you attached to an environment you know isn’t the best for your mental health, at least use that money to invest in yourself and stave off burnout.

Practice mindfulness

Often, it is our own racing or negative thoughts that trigger the body’s stress response. Inner self-critique, self-judgment, and worry about the past or future can easily activate fight or flight. Luckily, [mindfulness](https://wellness.ucsb.edu/challenges/happiness-challenge/ucsb-happiness-challenge/happiness-challenge-mindfulness) can help. By using some of the tools mentioned above (like wearables, or breathwork and meditation), lawyers can become more present, and thus more aware of their own internal dialogue, nervous system, and mood.

At the end of the day, stress responses cause [cognitive dysfunction](https://www.cambridgecognition.com/blog/entry/can-stress-at-work-affect-cognitive-performance) and an inability to problem-solve. So, worrying, stressing, and beating ourselves up will never lead to a better outcome in a situation where something can or has already gone awry. In contrast, being intentional with time, regulating the nervous system, and practicing mindfulness are scientifically proven to get you back on track quicker, so you can be more effective at navigating stressful situations and solving all those mounting problems — even the ones you created.

Also, it is important to bear in mind that a proficient recruiter can assist in improving your circumstances if your present firm is causing you stress, anxiety, and depression. Should you require guidance or resources for your legal career, please do not hesitate to personally [contact me or one of my colleagues](https://laterallink.com/directory-v2/) at [Lateral Link](https://laterallink.com/).

####Topics

# Morning Docket: 11.02.18
## * Justice Brett Kavanaugh isn't the only one who's relying upon calendars as a defense to sexual misconduct allegations. President Donald Trump says he'll turn over portions of his calendars and journal entries to combat allegations that he forcibly kissed Summer Zervos, a former Apprentice contestant. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/10/31/president-trump-disclose-calendars-summer-zervos-defamation-lawsuit/1836278002/)] * Do you support term limits or a mandatory retirement age for Supreme Court justices? If yes, then a majority of Americans agree with you. Fix the Court polled 1,000 people, and 78 percent of them said they'd like to restrict the length of service for SCOTUS justices. [[The Hill](https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/414264-majority-of-americans-support-term-limits-for-supreme-court-justices)] * Per a new survey conducted by Diversity Lab and ChIPs called the Inclusion Blueprint, the Biglaw firms with the best policies to build gender equity are Brooks Kushman and Sheppard Mullin. We may have more on this later. [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/new-survey-rates-big-law-policies-to-build-gender-equality/)] * Shocking absolutely no one, now that Cooley Law is magically in "compliance" with the American Bar Association's accreditation standards, the school has dropped its lawsuit against the ABA. This is terribly convenient, isn't it? [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/now_reportedly_in_compliance_with_admissions_standard_cooley_law_drops_suit)] * Ieshia Champs, the 33-year-old single mother of five children whose [inspirational graduation photos went viral](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ieshia-champs/) this past spring, recently found out that she passed the Texas bar exam. Congratulations! All of your hard work paid off! [[Fox 10 KSAZ](http://www.fox10phoenix.com/news/us-world-news/pasadena-single-mom-of-5-passes-bar-exam-after-graduating-law-school)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 2, 2018 at 8:28 AMNovember 4, 2018 at 8:48 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-02-18/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2011.02.18)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-02-18/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-02-18/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(SAUL LOEB/AFP/Getty Images)

* Justice Brett Kavanaugh isn’t the only one who’s relying upon calendars as a defense to sexual misconduct allegations. President Donald Trump says he’ll turn over portions of his calendars and journal entries to combat allegations that he forcibly kissed Summer Zervos, a former Apprentice contestant. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/10/31/president-trump-disclose-calendars-summer-zervos-defamation-lawsuit/1836278002/)]

* Do you support term limits or a mandatory retirement age for Supreme Court justices? If yes, then a majority of Americans agree with you. Fix the Court polled 1,000 people, and 78 percent of them said they’d like to restrict the length of service for SCOTUS justices. [[The Hill](https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/414264-majority-of-americans-support-term-limits-for-supreme-court-justices)]

# Wachtell Litigator George Conway Just Can't Help Slamming His Wife's Boss
## How embarrassing for the president, his ignorance is on display.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 30, 2020 at 10:43 AMJanuary 30, 2020 at 10:25 AM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/wachtell-litigator-george-conway-just-cant-help-slamming-his-wifes-boss/&text=Wachtell%20Litigator%20George%20Conway%20Just%20Can’t%20Help%20Slamming%20His%20Wife’s%20Boss)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/wachtell-litigator-george-conway-just-cant-help-slamming-his-wifes-boss/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/wachtell-litigator-george-conway-just-cant-help-slamming-his-wifes-boss/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo of Kellyanne Conway, George Conway, and their twins, via Kellyanne Conway’s Twitter feed.)

Listen, you’re a busy lawyer. You don’t have time to keep up with the vastness of the internet. Plus, in case you haven’t noticed, there is an impeachment trial going on. That spectacle, presided over by Chief Justice Roberts, is sucking any spare time you might have. But that doesn’t mean some hilarious ish isn’t going down on the interwebs.

Take, for example, the Twitter feed of George Conway. Conway is notable in Biglaw as a litigator at Wachtell who had some conservative-leaning political aspirations. But, as we all know by now, he is also married to counselor to the president Kellyanne Conway. And he doesn’t like his wife’s boss. Like, not at all. Like he’s started a fund, [The Lincoln Project](https://lincolnproject.us/), to make sure Trump gets defeated in 2020 and his wife is out of a job.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
As interesting as that is to watch from afar, Conway has doubled down on the Trump attacks. Just the other day, he went on a Twitter screed slamming the president for some of the most egregious mistakes he’s made while in office. It’s a shade-filled walk down memory lane; actually, it bypasses shade and gets to full-on dunking on the president. Anyway, it would be an entertaining thread regardless of who put it together, but once you know Conway’s personal connection to the president, well *chef’s kiss*.

Enjoy!

A thread for those who think [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) could find Ukraine on a marked map:

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222142875078725635?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

.[@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) seems to think Paris is in Germany. (It kind of was for a few years in the 1940s, I guess.) [https://t.co/RF5e3Rb1VO](https://t.co/RF5e3Rb1VO)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222143958047916033?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

Also, [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) didn’t understand that when it’s the afternoon in Washington, it’s the middle of the night in Tokyo. [https://t.co/1rRD1SOw0C](https://t.co/1rRD1SOw0C)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222145273729900545?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

I have to say that really is my personal favorite. [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) is there trashing the presidents of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia for the breakup Yugoslavia, and they’re like, WTF. And then it dons on them—Balkans, Baltics … buffoon.[https://t.co/ecZ4a9qOx1](https://t.co/ecZ4a9qOx1)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222149034841866240?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

Oh, wait. A small correction. [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) thought Nipple and Button were in India, not separate countries. My bad—we all make mistakes. Sorry. [https://t.co/TfvMJ05n9m](https://t.co/TfvMJ05n9m)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222150599841546246?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

.[@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) once got a call from the president of *South* Korea, but then told hundreds of journalists that he’d gotten a call from the leader of *North* Korea. [https://t.co/qtGtTS2WSf](https://t.co/qtGtTS2WSf)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222153049805852673?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

.[@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) once told the prime minister of India, “It’s not like you’ve got China on your border.” (India has a 2,520-mile border with China.)[https://t.co/U5ncPjFbbp](https://t.co/U5ncPjFbbp)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222155651616583680?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

… yet made the mistake again in 2019. [https://t.co/XsRCDJlxbe](https://t.co/XsRCDJlxbe)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222158160510799875?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

When Gordon Sondland called [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) on July 26 and said he was in Kyiv, Trump had to ask whether Sondland was in Ukraine, according to the testimony of embassy staffer David Holmes. [https://t.co/IXRiivo82z](https://t.co/IXRiivo82z) [pic.twitter.com/RGkFTYCZ15](https://t.co/RGkFTYCZ15)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222167861378064384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

.[@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) asked, “Why is Seoul so close to the North Korean border?”

And then, referring to the 10 million inhabitants of South Korea’s capital, he said, “They have to move!”[https://t.co/8JZTJQ5Qqt](https://t.co/8JZTJQ5Qqt)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222171615011786752?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

And in 2019, [@realDonaldTrump](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) remained blissfully ignorant, and confused about, the distinction between England and the UK. He seems to think that England changed its name. Maybe a branding thing. Who knows. [https://t.co/QIYE4lYTEd](https://t.co/QIYE4lYTEd)

— George Conway (@gtconway3d) [January 28, 2020](https://twitter.com/gtconway3d/status/1222201754726621185?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Michael Cohen Put Up His Home As Collateral -- Now What Are The Chances He'll Flip On Trump?
## Is Michael Cohen in a "fight for his family's financial life"?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 9, 2018 at 11:56 AM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/michael-cohen-put-up-his-home-as-collateral-now-what-are-the-chances-hell-flip-on-trump/&text=Michael%20Cohen%20Put%20Up%20His%20Home%20As%20Collateral%20—%20Now%20What%20Are%20The%20Chances%20He’ll%20Flip%20On%20Trump?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/michael-cohen-put-up-his-home-as-collateral-now-what-are-the-chances-hell-flip-on-trump/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/michael-cohen-put-up-his-home-as-collateral-now-what-are-the-chances-hell-flip-on-trump/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Michael Cohen (Photo by Mark Wilson/Getty Images)

Desperate men do desperate things. There’s now hope — at least amongst the segment of Americans opposed to President Trump — that Donald Trump’s fixer Michael Cohen might be a little closer to striking a deal with federal prosecutors and spilling all the tea on the president.

Bloomberg has a [new report](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-08/trump-lawyer-cohen-puts-up-family-apartment-against-bank-debts) that reveals, according to public filings, the taxi business owned by Cohen and his wife owes as much as $12.8 million on loans to Sterling Bank. That loan had been secured by taxi medallions, but with the success of Uber and other ride-hailing services, the value of that collateral has dropped 80 percent. Now the Cohens have placed their home as collateral on the debt owed to Sterling Bank:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Cohen and his wife have now pledged their apartment in the Trump Park Avenue — a 10th-floor spread combining three units — as additional collateral to the bank, which valued it at $9 million, according to filings of the April 22 transaction.

The exact details of the transaction are unclear — indeed, in a text to Bloomberg Cohen puffed, “With all due respect, you don’t remotely understand my loan.” But the experts have some insight into what may be going on behind the filings:

“It looks to me like the lender probably said you have to guarantee these existing loans, and by the way you have to pledge your real estate to backstop your guaranty,” said Joshua Stein, a Manhattan real-estate attorney who reviewed the public filings.

The next best question is whether this new information about Cohen’s finances increases the likelihood he will cooperate with the government investigation. Certainly some commentators think this “fight for his family’s financial life” puts a lot more pressure on him:

Breaking: [@CalebMelby](https://twitter.com/CalebMelby?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) report suggests Michael Cohen may face more pressure to flip as he fights for his family's financial life – Caleb joins us at 6pm

Plus reporting on the criminal probe into former AG Schneiderman with [@nancyerikasmith](https://twitter.com/nancyerikasmith?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) & [@LeahRigueur](https://twitter.com/LeahRigueur?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw);

Iran;

CIA torture…

— Ari Melber (@AriMelber) [May 8, 2018](https://twitter.com/AriMelber/status/993938823208939520?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

The reality is fighting the full resources of the federal government in court takes a lot of your own resources.[ Much has been made](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-27/will-cohen-cooperate-tenuous-finances-may-provide-crucial-clues) before about Cohen’s struggling taxi business and the financial strain he appears to be under. Now that we know Cohen doesn’t have the value of his home to leverage in his legal battle, well, the prospect of being a government witness seems a lot better.

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# The Biglaw Firms Where Lawyers Did The Most Pro Bono Work (2022)
## Which law firms were the best at giving back?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 11, 2023 at 3:15 PMJuly 11, 2023 at 5:10 PM
27
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/the-biglaw-firms-where-lawyers-did-the-most-pro-bono-work-2022/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Where%20Lawyers%20Did%20The%20Most%20Pro%20Bono%20Work%20(2022))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/the-biglaw-firms-where-lawyers-did-the-most-pro-bono-work-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/the-biglaw-firms-where-lawyers-did-the-most-pro-bono-work-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Law schools across the country are gearing up for early interview week, and many students have their future careers on their minds. With so many things to take into account when considering their livelihoods, how can law students create meaningful distinction between firms? Perhaps they can take a look at the firms’ pro bono numbers.

Over the course of the last year, members of the legal profession sprang into action to deal with crisis after crisis after crisis, offering their services without cost to those in need. From immigration and asylum work thanks to the war in Ukraine to racial justice initiatives to protecting reproductive rights in America’s post-Dobbs legal landscape, lawyers across the country were inspired to do their very best to help those who needed their assistance the very most.

But which law firms were able to contribute the most to society?

The American Lawyer has compiled a ranking of Am Law 200 firms based on their pro bono work in 2022. Half of their scores come from the average number of pro bono hours per lawyer, while the other half represents the percentage of lawyers who performed more than 20 hours of pro bono work.

Here are the top 10 firms for the rocky legal year that was 2022:

- Covington & Burling
- Munger Tolles & Olson
- Jenner & Block
- Orrick
- Arnold & Porter
- WilmerHale
- Patterson Belknap
- Hughes Hubbard
- Dechert
- Hogan Lovells
It should be noted that at [each firm listed](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/07/11/post-pandemic-reset-affects-pro-bono-hours-in-2022/), the average attorney performed 133.7 hours or more of pro bono work last year, and the Am Law 200 as a whole contributed about 5.01 million hours of pro bono work. These numbers are up from 2021, but still lag behind the hellish year that was 2020 (when the Am Law 200 contributed 5.45 million hours of pro bono work), but leaders in the pro bono space know that meaningful pro bono work is still widely available for attorneys. “The need is just so great now,” said Debbie Berman, co-chair of Jenner & Block’s pro bono practice, in an Am Law interview.

Congratulations to the Biglaw firms where attorneys chose compassion during yet another busy year. Your efforts will not be forgotten.

[The 2023 Pro Bono Scorecard: National Report](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/07/11/the-2023-pro-bono-scorecard-national-rankings/) [American Lawyer]

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Making Their Mark: How Millennial Lawyers Could Reshape The Industry
## Read on for a deep dive into this generation’s priorities and goals.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onJune 16, 2021 at 5:02 PMJuly 8, 2021 at 11:14 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/making-their-mark-how-millennial-lawyers-could-reshape-the-industry/&text=Making%20Their%20Mark:%20How%20Millennial%20Lawyers%20Could%20Reshape%20The%20Industry)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/making-their-mark-how-millennial-lawyers-could-reshape-the-industry/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/making-their-mark-how-millennial-lawyers-could-reshape-the-industry/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As the legal industry begins to emerge from the pandemic lockdown, millennial lawyers are poised to play a key role in reshaping its future operations.

And in today’s environment of salary wars and ever-growing lawyer demand, law firms must intensify their focus on attracting millennial talent to remain competitive.

To help law firms better understand millennial lawyers and evolving workplace dynamics, we have partnered with our friends at Major, Lindsey & Africa for the third time to dig deep into the cultural changes that this generation has brought to law firms.

We surveyed the Above the Law audience to find out about the priorities and goals of millennial lawyers, as well as generational differences that may exist between this group and its older counterparts.

Fill out the form below to receive the free report detailing our findings.

####Topics
[Associates](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/associates/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Career Files](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/career-files/), [Gender](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/gender/), [Lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/lawyers-career-files/), [Major Lindsey & Africa](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/major-lindsey-africa/), [Millennials](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/millennials/), [MLA](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/mla/), [MLA custom](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/mla-custom/), [Race](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/race/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Surveys](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/surveys/)
